turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: No sir it doesn’t.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: No sir it does not.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I suggest to you again that it's a very good point that you’re defending a judgment below you have now the opinion other than the(Inaudible)

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Yes sir, in other words -- thank you sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You can even defend on the ground that it's right.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: [Laughter] Well, what we are taking the position is that regardless of whether or not the Administrative Procedure Act said this or not that due process requires this and Mr. Justice Brennan in Goldberg said in almost every setting where important decisions turn on questions of fact, Due Process requires an opportunity to confront and cross examine adverse witnesses.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Notice, he said almost.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Not in every situation and you have to read that in the light of what was decided there.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Namely that the hearing officers were not totally independent.
It wasn’t the total adversary due process.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Well, Your Honor what the Government is saying, when it comes to other cases where the poor people are involved really doesn’t rely on this concept of inherent rightness of the doctor’s reports.
In cases involving the revocation of a pilots license for example where a $40,000.00 or $50,000.00 job maybe at stake.
The FAA does not simply allow introduction of reports but they go ahead and allow the pilot to put on his doctor.
The FAA puts on their doctor and then the hearing examiner after evaluating that testimony, not the reports, goes ahead and makes a decision.

And so the Government is seeming to take the position when there are a lot of cases and where poor people are involved, we have one standard and where there are few cases and more affluent people involved, we have a different stand.
Basically, the Solicitor General took the position that it really doesn’t make any difference that the doctor is just going to get up and read his report and that’s all there is to it.
Well, as a member of the trial bar, who has tried a number of cases, I will say to you that in my opinion this is the real key.
This makes a tremendous difference as to whether you can win or lose your case as to whether you can cross examine the doctors who are relied upon by the Government.
Many doctors, for example, we see everyday --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well if that’s much difference why didn’t you call a doctor?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Because it's our position, first the practical matter.
You recall the Government doctors get paid a $125.00, if we subpoena them they get paid the witness fee of $20.00.
In our area, it is unethical with agreement with the medical associations to subpoena a doctor without paying him his reasonable fee as set up between the bar.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I thought the Government would pay him?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: They pay him the $20.00 witness fee Your Honor and nothing more.

Not any stipend like they pay their own doctor and so what we are faced with if we have to call their doctors, is we have to pay his fee for coming and attempting to disprove the Government’s case which is a practical matter.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Do social security taxes support disability?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Yes sir, they do.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In other words, your client has been making contributions toward disability as well as the other benefits.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Yes sir he has.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, would you have any real objection here if the Government said to you “look, we give you your choice.
You can either get a subpoena out to the doctor or not.”
Now you have got your choice of either we are going to use either the report or the doctor which every one you say.
Now we are going to -- I mean that happens to be the rule and you just don’t have to call the doctor at that time --

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Well I think what you’re basically saying if you take that position Mr. Justice White is that we are not only having to prove our case but then once the Government simply puts in a report, we have to go forward and disprove the Government’s case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well that’s a different point but on the point you were making, would have any real complain as the Government says?
You just tell us what you want, the report or the doctor?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Well we -- In other words we would always say we want you to bring the doctor here and you pay them, yes sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You would always say that.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Even though you’ve got an expert that your going to call?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Yes sir because we are found -- Mr. Justice White it's been my experience that we have found that many of these doctors in their reports will say this man has a 20% disability which means of course, he doesn’t have a total disability but this same doctor will testify when he comes to a hearing that the only way he will give a man a 100% disability, if he is paralyzed from the neck down.

And unless he is bedridden he gives -- it doesn’t give people a 100% disability and the further thing that is shown here in this very case where in the workmans compensation proceedings, the doctors had to be called and had to testify, that fact finder found that he was totally and permanently disabled.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What does he do now?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: He does not do anything sir.

I think if really -- if the Government really believed that these doctors reports were so inherently -- such inherent probative value, why wouldn’t they just simply take the claimants doctor’s report and dispense with all these independent doctors.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Was it his own physician indicated that there was some psychosomatic involvement here?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: His own physician indicated that there was an emotional overlay and this together that these two factors that prior to the injury he was able to go out and earn a living even with the pre-existing emotional overlay.
But with the back condition that he had and emotional overlay that he had partly brought about on by his destitute circumstances.
In social security cases, you cannot even apply until you have been unemployed for six months.
And in this case, the hearing wasn’t held until he had been out of work for over a year-and-a-half.
So, generally these people are pretty destitute by the time, they get to a hearing examiner and anyone who’s been out for a year and a half is going to have some emotional overlay.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Tinsman, what would you say if instead of calling these -- using these panels of doctors, specialists if these matters were referred to the panel of specialists to act as triers and let make them make the decision, you wouldn’t expect that you could cross examine a hearing officer would you?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: No sir but in effect what your saying is allow the medical adviser to be the hearing officer as to medical disability, is that correct?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Would you think that was unconstitutional or otherwise --

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Well, I would say this Mr. Chief Justice that unless at the hearing before the hearing officer that you allowed the man to have the cross examination of the doctors who opposed the contention of his doctor that this would be a denial of due process.
Now, if you allowed a doctor to be a hearing examiner that would be fine.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Perhaps that’s -- you see no objection in the statute of the constitution to having filed in a situation like this referred to the doctors and let their decision be made as the determiners and triers of the issue.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Well, it depends on how -- I don’t agree that just the file should be referred to them Your Honor.
Maybe the testimony as taken down and if you make them the final arbitrar on all medical questions.
This would be -- in other words you would be making them the independent fact finder and this would be constitutionally permissible.
But one of the problems is who do you accept as a doctor?

The state agencies many times select doctors who because they are attempting to hold down the cost of their own disability programs are generally very conservative and are hesitant to find disability in a man particularly where it means that money will be paid out of the public treasury.

And this is the type of doctor generally that is selected by the state agencies and example is Dr. Levitt here who would find no one disabled unless they were -- even if they had both arms and both legs off.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: He didn’t quite put it that way did he?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: No he didn’t quite put it that way but I think it indicates his thinking.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Tinsman, let me bring you back to the merits.
How many specialists had reports in this man's file on him?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: This man has been seen by Dr. Munslow who was a doctor of the --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How many, how many?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: As I recall there were four Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Four.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: And then there was an additional one we submitted to the appeals counsel, so five.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What would you do as an attorney?
Would you demand all five physicians show up at this hearing?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: No sir I do not say that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What would you do -- what would you do?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: In other words, I would say that the Government has to have at least one doctor.
Specialist or non specialist.
In other words, they have to have some substantial evidence.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, suppose one showed up, would you object to his reference to the reports of the other four?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: It depends on what the other four found, if the other four were finding subjective things such as non cooperation and things of that.
I would object to that.
If they were simply referring to actual positive tests like a reading of an x-ray or reading of a --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Suppose they contained what they usually contain, the diagnosis, would you object that?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Yes, I would object to them referring to another doctor’s diagnosis, I would say you have to testify from what you found just as in this --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you want -- in this case you would insist on five physicians being subpoenaed?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: No sir I would not.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: To be in present.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: No sir, I would not.
I would insist on only one being present and if the Government had one present and he testified, then this would be for the hearing examiner to evaluate.
Not all five present and I would say this.
There was one specialist who we found out later because normally reports to the state welfare agency are not open to the claimant.

We found that a specialist in the same office as of Dr. Langston who was relied on by the Government who is a partner of his had found does man did have a post operative herniated disc but we couldn’t find that out until later because this report was not made available to us.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why still -- I don’t understand why the Government has in effect said to you look Mr. claimant, do you know we were going to rely on reports of that of doctors but all you have to do is tell us and we will have the doctors there by subpoena, do you want them?
Why isn’t that the practical situation?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: The practical situation is not there Your Honor because number one; they don’t have the subpoena that you request and secondly even if they do --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But you didn’t even ask them.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: That’s right because we take the position that what in effect then you are requiring us to do is not only prove our case but we have to come in -- if we put the witnesses on and disprove the Government’s case and what if these witnesses testify adversely?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What would happen to these doctors, the Government might well putting on in the case or there is any formality at all, the Government might prefer that have relied testimony of the doctor if he was there.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Well, they had a second hearing Your Honor in this case, the Government did not choose to call their doctors and the second hearing that brought in --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You didn’t choose to ask them to be there either.
All you had to do is say so and they would have been there.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Well, from the reports they certainly wouldn’t have helped us and so it was our position --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Exactly, and you had -- you tell me that you would always have the doctor there, if you thought that doctor is going to hurt you, you would not have him there, because he’s going to help you, you would have him there.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: If I was calling him directly.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All you had to do is ask as far as we know the Government would have had the doctor there and you did not ask.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: But if I had to have a choice between the report being relied on by the hearing examiner or the doctor’s personal testimony being relied on by the hearing examiner, even though I knew both were adverse to me, I would rather ask the doctors there.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well then why didn’t you ask the doctor to be there?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Well, it was a decision that we made that we felt that if we had asked the doctor to be there in effect number one; we would be vouching for the doctor, number two we would have had to pay for the doctor --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well I don’t know how you stick with the Government with some agreement by your local bar association that you pay doctors.
And if you issue subpoena for the doctor, he’s going to show up.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Yes Sir but I have to continue to practice law in that community and if you do this as a practical matter, there are going to be some doctors that will always give your clients --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But there is due process claim on that.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: No, we’re not building -- in other words what we’re saying is that we just don’t have this obligation to an effect disprove the Government’s reports.
In effect, this would mean that in any administrative hearing if the Government put on the report of a lawyer or an engineer or anything else --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Did they tell you in advance, we are going to rely on the written reports unless you want the live testimony there.
Now if you want the doctors there you just tell us we’ll have him there even before the hearing even starts.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Let me say this as a practical matter Mr. Justice White, they don’t tell you that.

They say the reports were going to rely on can be examined you on the morning of the hearing or in the examiners office and he is in Houston and it's not feasible to go 200 miles to look at the reports that happen to be in his office, we have written --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Are you suggesting you didn’t know you have the right to subpoena the doctor?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Oh we knew that we had the right to subpoena the doctor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You know choice you had?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: We did not know all of the reports that he had in his file, some of the reports Your Honor, in fact all social security reports that are made are not released to the claimant.

It's against social security -- we have attempted to get them in other cases in the Federal District Court and the social security administrations has come in and said this are not to be released to the claimant the man that was examined.

Because under the federal regulations they’re absolutely privileged so the only time you can see them is when the hearing examiner's file is open to you which means either going to Houston to look at them or on the morning of the hearing.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Tinsman, suppose the examiner says that I'm going to appoint a medical advisor and I've instructed not only to look at the reports but to personally examine the man.
And that doctor testified is that --

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: In other words --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Would that satisfy you?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Yes sir that would satisfy me.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So the only difference is that the medical advisor didn’t personally examine the man.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: That is correct Your Honor and it's our position that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That’s your only point?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: No, no, no that’s our point on the medical advisor.
Our point is that the Government’s evidence as to no disability was only reports.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Except that my report was based on the reports of the other doctors plus my personal examination of the man.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: I would object to that, I would say his opinion could be only on his examination of the man.
In other --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well suppose that happens to agree with the reports --

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Well that’s another matter.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You mean, you don't want to read the reports?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: I think, he can read the reports but he must form his own independent evaluation.
In other words he can say, I read this reports and I disagree with them.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That would satisfy you?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Yes sir that would satisfy me.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That’s all you want?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: What we want is a man that’s examined him to testify in the hearing, yes sir and our position on this medical advisor thing is if they really believe in these doctors whose reports they say are inherently right, why don’t they just bring one of those doctors to be the medical advisor rather than bringing in a man who has never examined the man.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: By the way who has got the burden of proof, the claimant?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: The claimant has the burden of proof Your Honor and he has the burden of proof and --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So had the Government asking you to prove your case is that really turning things around?

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Well, when we bring our doctor who testifies that this man is totally disabled, Your Honor we feel that we have met our burden of proof and then the burden of -- if the Government wishes to contest this, then they must come in with proof that says no, your doctor is wrong, he is not disabled.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What if Congress has passed a law and allowed these people to sue in Court but provided in the law hearsay evidence would be admissible.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Well, I think Your Honor that if we really feel that what Mr. Justice Brennan said in Goldberg is that in almost every setting where important decisions turn on questions of fact due process requires an opportunity to confront and cross examine adverse witnesses that this would be highly suspect as a violation of due process.
That Congress cannot provide this.
Now the Court said that almost every situation is for this Court to determine which are the exemptions.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Tinsman.
Mr. Friedman we've gone considerably over, if you have some more observations we’ll give you some additional time here.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Thank you Mr.--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How much do you think would --

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Oh I think another five minutes would certainly be plenty.
I would like at the outset just make three little factual points.
First, in the previous discussion over the role of the examiner in this case I want to make it clear these examiners are appointed under the Administrative Procedure Act.
They are the typical APA examiners who presided normal agency hearings.
They are not under the control of the sector of health, education and welfare.
They are independent examiners.
Now another point was made and I've been advised by the social security people that if a witness is subpoenaed at the request of the claimant.
The Government will pay with a reasonable fee for his appearance.

I'm also told that if a request is made to examine the file prior to the hearing and if the hearing examiner's office is 200 to 250 miles away, arrangements can be made to temporarily send a file to a local place where the man is, so that the claimant or his attorney can examine it.
Now finally, I think it is important and on the two aspects of the case.
First, on the medical examiner's testimony, it seems to me that basically what the medical examiner is doing in this case is pretty much the same thing --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Medical adviser you mean?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: The medical adviser, I'm sorry if I misspoke myself.
The medical adviser is doing this case with any expert witness is doing.
The only difference is in the case of the traditional expert witness in Court he gives his opinion in response to a hypothetical question.

A whole string of hypothesis have put together and I take it if in his case the examiner had attempted to summarize the medical reports that have bee presented and then to summarize what had been testified to at the hearing, there will no objection to the adviser giving his expert judgment on that basis.
Now certainly, in this kind of an informal procedure that we have in these hearings, I don’t think, there's any need to resort to such formalism.

The examiner made it very clear in his questions put to the medical examiner that he was asking the medical examiner to give his opinion on the basis of the material included in the reports on the basis of the testimony.
And to whatever extent there might be any infirmities in the reports, to whatever extent there might be reasons that the report should not be accepted, that was clear on the record.
This is not a case of a jury having to have medical expert opinion solicited on the basis of hypothetical questions because otherwise they might assume facts that had been proven.
This is an informal administrative proceeding.
Now, the charge has been made here that the examiner is unfair, that this whole proceeding is unfair and it references to the statement of the need for cross examination and so on.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now does the statute use the word unfair?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, no the statute Mr. Justice says that the secretary shall -- it says the secretary shall have full power to make rules and regulations and shall adapt reasonable and proper rules and regulations to regulate and provide for the nature and extent of the proofs and the evidence and the method of taking and furnishing to say.
And then under that statute, the secretary has adopted regulations which give the examiner broad authority to conduct the hearings as he sees fit.
And he says that it's within the discretion of the examiner to determine the procedure or hearings generally provided that such nature is for the parties a reasonable opportunity for a fair hearing.
We think that has been given and we think the fairness of this is demonstrated by the fact that in at least a third of these cases, the claimant prevails after the hearing.

And I suppose, in many instances it maybe that when the examiner sees the claimant before him, he gets a different view that the examiner's judgment as to what the report show and what their significance is.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Friedman is the hearing of this kind of case a full time job for this presenter?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Yes.
This is --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That’s all they do?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: This is all they do and I might say that these examiners prior to the time they start on the job, they get some kind of a course in which they get some basic medical information, like a six or eight week course in which they are instructed, I understand by various specialists in the field.

And certainly when -- as I said the proceeding is not an adversary one and the failure of the claimant in this case even to request that these witnesses be made available, he is never subpoenaed, I mean the Court of Appeals, he doesn’t (Inaudible).
The Court of Appeals itself in this case recognized that his failure to call the witnesses precluded him from complaining at the fact they weren’t there for cross examination.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What if the congress had passed a law providing cases against private insurance companies could be tried under the same statute and then the finding of the secretary would be final?
What would you say about that?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well in effect, I would think, it would again depend on what kind of case it was.
There might be some problems with the Seventh Amendment on the right to a jury trial but we do have --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It would be wouldn’t it?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Yes but we do have a similar kind of proceeding Mr. Justice under the Harbor Workmans Compensation statute which traditionally you have it held before a deputy commissioner and that is there are two parties -- there's usually the claimant on the one hand and the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That’s against the Government, that’s the difference.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That is a Government case, yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: There's a difference in both these cases.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That is correct, that is right this is the Government and the Government I think, can in dealing with these many problems resort to these more informal procedures that have been developed in recent years.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Freedman, thank you Mr. Tinsman.
Mr. Tinsman, you acted at the Courts request and our appointment.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We thank you for your assistance to -- not only the petitioner here but your assistance to the Court.

turn.speaker: richard_tinsman
turn.label: Mr. Richard Tinsman
turn.text: Thank you very much.
